citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, the program of veterinary care for dogs and other animals, the environmental enhancement plan for
birds, and the acquisition records for two pigs were not available for review by the inspector.
Review of records required by the Animal Welfare Act facilitates the inspection process by allowing the inspector to
determine compliance and evaluate animal welfare. The facility must ensure that the records required to be kept by the
Animal Welfare Act and the regulations are updated, complete and available for USDA APHIS officials to review at time of
inspection.
Correct from this day, 01/16/2026, forward.

The metal posts along the bottom of an approximately 6ft. section of the chain link fencing between two primary dog
enclosures housing 5 dogs were stained dark brown and had excessively rusted surfaces with areas of flaking and pitting
metal. Surfaces that contain excessive rust cannot be adequately cleaned and sanitized and may increase the risk of
disease hazards. Any surfaces that come in contact with the dogs must be free of excessive rust that prevents the
required cleaning and sanitization.
Correct by 01/29/2026.

An approximately 2ft X 3ft sheet of metal at the bottom part of a fenced gate within a primary dog enclosure housing 3
dogs was worn and bent inward along one corner with sharp points and edges. Failure to maintain primary enclosures in
good repair with no sharp points or edges within contact of the dogs may result in injury to the dogs. Primary enclosures
for dogs must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the dogs.
Correct by 01/26/2026.

At time of inspection, the water bowl within the enclosure for two adult dogs was empty. According to the facility
representative, the bowl was filled earlier in the morning. A caretaker provided water for the dogs which drank a small
amount calmly and comfortably without notable thirst. Constant access to potable water is necessary to ensure that dogs
remain adequately hydrated as needed throughout the day. The facility must ensure that all dogs have continuous access
to potable water at all times, unless restricted by the attending veterinarian or excepted as provided in 3.17(a).
Correct from this day, 01/16/2026, forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
